Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of insulin allergy, coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and poorly controlled diabetes mellitus (IDDM). The patient presented with urticaria and suspected angioedema related to insulin preparations. He was admitted to the ICU for allergy and endocrine consultation for insulin desensitization. The patient has been experiencing a worsening rash that is temporally associated with insulin administration, leading to concerns about a possible insulin allergy. Multiple etiologies for the rash have been considered, including insulin allergy, allergic/rheumatologic phenomenon, and celiac sprue with dermatitis herpetiformis. Endocrinology, allergy, and dermatology services have been consulted and involved in the patient's care. Additional studies are pending to investigate other potential causes. The patient's blood glucose levels were initially very high (>400) but are now under better control. Due to repeated incidents of hyperglycemia, the patient will be started on glyburide 5 mg PO BID and will attempt to hold glucose as tolerated until novalog can be obtained. Other ongoing assessments and plans include monitoring for low TSH levels, managing CAD/HTN, hyperlipidemia, diverticulitis/ulcerative colitis, and providing prophylactic treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers. The patient is currently receiving nutrition through the enteral route, and efforts are being made to establish more peripheral access. The patient's code status is full code, and his current disposition is in the ICU.
